The writer is absolutely correct. As an M.D. I've witnessed insurers playing the same computer-complaint card with a law passed in 2008 that required them to stop collecting social security numbers from solo private practices for claims payments and instead to use the NPI number. They whined that the computer issue was too complicated, got a one year extension, then another one year extension. Many still have not made the change five years later (e.g. Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of NJ). To my mind, these are just stalling tactics and we will likely see more of them, especially if they are rewarded in this way.
Might just as well send a note to the insurance company lobbyists while you're at it.

This is promulgated through new media like the NYT that do not take a truly critical stance on whether these promises will pan out. Brochures for the ACA also make these statements. The republicans and democrats and the industries are all in agreement, though they pretend to be different, the policies implemented always have the same outcome regardless of which party is around.

Indeed, extremely, vanishingly small cases of fraud.

In fact, one would have to be rather deranged to even logically come to the conclusion that voting twice or even 10 times would ever have any meaningful impact on an election. And logically you also must conclude that a teensy amount of fraud for one candidate is cancelled out be a teensy bit of fraud being committed on behalf of the other candidate. It's entirely a non-issue.

I lived in NC for 20 years. Every election cycle I'd go down to my polling station where my neighbor, a Republican, would check me off the list on nothing more than my recognizance. That, I realize in retrospect, was a beautiful thing.  I actually find it hard to believe that the majority of North Carolinians, or even 20% of North Carolinians, Republican or Democrat, favor losing that affirmation of our dignity and belief in one another's basic honesty.  Yes, surely, there must have been the occasional fraud, but a small price to pay for liberty and enfranchising all honest NC voters. The NC legislature have taken that dignity away and replaced it with a paranoid and bald attempt to disenfranchise a whole segment of the NC population that, through a host factors largely beyond their control, has little more than it's dignity and honesty to trade on in the first place. A shameful thing.

You forgot to add refusing to extend Medicaid, thus resulting in about half a million North Carolinians being without medical insurance and now, the start of closures of health clinics frequented by the poor. And the significant cutback of early voting days, even though almost a third of the state early voted. And forcing parents to choose between allowing their college kids to vote where they go to school (even when they have proper ID) and listing them as dependents on their tax returns. And citizens registering same day as voting (even with proper ID). And closing polls at a certain hour in the evening even if there are still people with proper ID standing on line. And allowing "research groups" to approach and interrogate properly ID'd citizens while they stand on line waiting to vote. And taking a firearm into a privately owned business establishment when the owner of said business instead wants his property to be gun free. Yeah, I see your point. Pretty extremist, all those lazy malcontent freeloaders.

James, I'm not sure, but you don't really sound like a Constitutional Scholar. So prove me wrong. Exactly where in that great body does it protect the right to conceal your weapons? The second amendment guarantees the right to bear arms in a well-regulated militia. The strict Constructionists have it wrong that this implies anyone can own any weapon and brandish it at any time.

As for voter ID laws, you understand that out of the hundreds of millions of votes cast for the US Presidency, only 82 were proven to be fraudulent? Now, I agree that's abhorrent. But to deny hundreds of thousands their constitutional right to vote because they don't have a driver's license or other photo ID is clearly more resatrictive than worrying about voter fraud that has never and will never substantially influence a race.
